body: ah yes, blocks, we've had quite a few discussions about this on the ML, it's more a matter of when it will happen. It wouldn't just be jade though it would be best to abstract more if possible so that ejs and friends can benefit as well, we just need to expose the buffering
This would be awesome.
yes please.... I really love jade but this is a blocker for the moment.

one downside is that since jade is not freely typed we cant just have {block start}  foo { block end} or whatever like django (looks bad anyway), but I'm sure we can figure something reasonable out. I still haven't come across much that you can't just do with variables, for example: https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/examples/extending-templates/views/users/index.html#L1

alternatively we would have some jade for that, not that it looks a ton better but hey:

```
block title
  Users

block head
  script(src=...)
  script(src=...)
```

I think the django stuff looks ok in the layout but mannnnn is it ever ugly in the user.html :( so many blocks and so little content. I thought about creating something similar to django/liquid for node but something a lot less verbose

I personally love how blocks help me think in reverse to partials (is that right?). I create "opportunities" to fill out a template. It creates a free-feeling writing style and very easy to wrap my head around. When I am interested in blocks, but have to use partials, It's like mentally reversing a mirror... or something. It's the reciprocal of how I _want_ to **think** about it thereby adding a layer of conceptual juggling.

well they are quite different things, neither of which are confusing in my mind at least, they just accomplish different things. partials are just "i have an object and want the template representation for it", blocks are just "i have a placeholder, alter it if you want", I dont think either replace the other they just compliment each other

Hey TJ, sorry if I wasn't clear. I completely agree and " "i have a placeholder, alter it if you want" " is precisely what I mean by "opportunity" with blocks.

I would never ever want blocks OR partials, but like you say blocks AND partials.

It's just that right now without blocks partials come to the rescue 100% of the time, even when my brain would prefer to think/design in blocks. Make sense?
totally. alot of these things can be solved just with the variables like i posted above but for more complex things like menus and sidebars etc yeah I think we could use this

Variables are certainly a fine replacement for blocks in most cases.  Your last statement makes a lot of sense regarding block usage for organizing larger chunks where I might what to swap out which partial I'm using for a nav, etc.

I also wanted to (re)touch upon the "extends" too.  Having to change folder structure to adjust the "layout" used for a given page doesn't _always_ make sense.  In most cases, the paths don't really matter (since routing in the app will take care of url organization), but there are cases where it could be very beneficial.  As an example (off the top of my head): what if I want a mobile vs desktop layout; the app layer could determine (user agent, cookie, ...) and add a data flag to switch ("extends") layout but still route to the same content template.  Obviously there are many other cases where this type of inheritance could be useful in keeping views organized and maintainable.
@jswartwood you're referring to the guessing express does for layouts? it could certainly just be a default when nothing explicit is given
Hooray!  Thank you much, TJ.
np :) figured I would try it out, and I like it, so it's in! in the future it might be worth adding the concept of prepending / appending to blocks as well
Thanks TJ, awesome.

I haven't had time to try the new release, so I might be missing some context (in regard to Jade at least) but I'm not sure I know exactly what you mean by "prepending/appending to blocks".  Are you thinking about it as allowing the blocks _wrappers_ similar to `extends` (as prepend, append, or both)?
@jswartwood not sure, I'm not overly familiar with django, that could be the same thing

@visionmedia I was speaking in terms of how the `extends` works in jade now but scoping to blocks.  Sorry, if I was unclear.  "wrappers" was just an arbitrary term I used to describe the relationship of the extended ("layout") & extending jade files.  Did you mean allowing blocks to extend other blocks or were you thinking something simpler for prepend/append?

(Not trying to steer this feature... just trying to visualize what you had in mind).

I was thinking something like say layout.jade:

```
html
  head
    block scripts
      script(src='/jquery.js')
```

index.jade:

```
extends layout

append scripts
  script(src='/myspecificscript.js')
  script(src='/anotherscript.js')
```

not sure if django has similar

I see... instead of index `block` overwriting always, it can append/prepend to layout `block`.

Interesting... that is an extremely common use case for me in templating systems. I typically accomplish this manually by having just having an[other] empty `block` to fill.  More slots to fill == more namespace clutter; so I would definitely appreciate this addition.

Either way, I appreciate the all the work you've done so far... one of these days I'll stop being such a lazy dev and dive into the jade src :)  It looks like prepend/append may be simple enough to implement: add terms to the lexer and funcs to the parser.  I guess my problem is mainly with github - there are just **too many** good projects out there to read them all :)

Also, I'm not sure about django either. I don't know it _that_ well; I'm more of a hobbyist with that framework. I was just using it to illustrate my `extends` request initially, since I had remembered seeing similar there first :)

yeah I was thinking that too, you can currently override a block to provide other blocks within it, so in doing so you could probably accomplish the same thing but definitely not as clean. yup it should be pretty simple to implement, i'll try it out today
